doc.field: Study and application of transient characteristics of fluid phenomena for downhole (oil and gas) pulsating devices using FLUENT ANSYS Estudo e aplicação de características transitórias de fenômenos de fluidos para dispositivos de pulsação de poços (petróleo e gás) usando FLUENT ANSYS Estudio y aplicación de características transitorias de fenómenos de fluidos para dispositivos de pulsación de pozos (petróleo y gas) usando FLUENT ANSYS Bharat Pawar Koustubh Kumbhar Timothy Hunter Harit Naik Abstract A fluctuating fluid flow inthe wellbore can provide intangible benefits in well stimulation applications. A pulsating device (PD) is a device with no moving parts that generates an oscillating jet of fluid at predesigned frequencies. Figure 1 shows the conceptual basis of a PD is the Coanda effect (Webb etal., 2006), which is the tendency of a fluid jet to be attracted to a nearby surface. Figure 2 illustrates the PD producing emissions of alternating bursts of fluid that create pulsating pressure waves within the wellbore and perforations (if present). As each burst is ejected, it forms a compressive wave within the wellbore fluid. As the wave passes through the formation and reflects back, it incurs a tensile loading on the skin damage. Continued cycling of these pressure waves causes the skin damage to reach its fatigue failure point. Scale is fatigued to failure then removed as a result of the fluidic oscillation, helping restore and enhance the permeability of the perforations in the near wellbore (NWB) area. Another benefit for the PD is in optimizing the placement of treatment fluids into the NWB area, yielding better contact coverage and thus better treatment results. keywords: ■ coanda effect ■ perforations ■ wellbore ■ formation Resumo Um fluxo de fluido flutuante no poço pode fornecer benefícios intangíveis em aplicações de estimulação. Um dispositivo pulsante (PD) é um dispositivo sem partes móveis que gera um jato oscilante de fluido em frequências pré-designadas. A Figura 1 mostra a base conceitual de uma PD é o efeito Coanda (Webb et al., 2006), que é a tendência de um jato de fluido ser atraído para uma superfície próxima. A Figura 2 ilustra a PD produzindo emissões de rajadas alternadas de fluido que criam ondas de pressão pulsantes dentro do poço e perfurações (quando presente). À medida que cada explosão é ejetada, ela forma uma onda compressiva dentro do fluido de poço. À medida que a onda passa através da formação e reflete de volta, ela incorre em um esforço de tração no dano da pele. O ciclo contínuo dessas ondas de pressão causa danos na pele para atingir seu ponto de fadiga. A Escala é cansada até a falha, em seguida, removida como resultado da oscilação fluídica, ajudando a restaurar e aumentar a permeabilidade das perfurações na área do poço próximo (NWB). Outro benefício para a PD é otimizar a colocação de fluidos de tratamento na área NWB, proporcionando melhor cobertura de contato e, portanto, melhores resultados de tratamento. palavras-chave: ■ efeito coanda ■ perfurações ■ poço ■ formação Resumen Un flujo de fluido flotante en el pozo puede proporcionar beneficios intangibles en aplicaciones de estimulación. Un dispositivo pulsante (PD) es un dispositivo sin partes móviles que genera un chorro oscilante de fluido en frecuencias predefinidas. La Figura 1 muestra la base conceptual de una PD es el efecto Coanda (Webb etal., 2006), que es la ten-dencia de un chorro de fluido a ser atraído hacia una superficie cercana. La Figura 2 ilustra la PD produciendo emisiones de ráfagas alternadas de fluido que crean ondas de presión pulsantes dentro del pozo y perforaciones (cuando están presentes). A medida que cada explosión es expulsada, forma una onda compresiva dentro del fluido de pozo. A medida que la onda pasa a través de la formación y se refleja de vuelta, ella incurre en un esfuerzo de tracción en el dano de la piel. El ciclo continuo de estas ondas de presión causa danos en la piel para alcanzar su punto de fatiga. La Escala es cansada hasta la falla, luego removida como resultado de la oscilación fluídica, ayudando a restaurar y aumentar la permeabilidad de las perforaciones en el área del pozo próximo (NWB). Otro beneficio para la PD es optimizar la colo-cación de fluidos de tratamiento en el área NWB, proporcionando mejor cobertura de contacto y, por lo tanto, mejores resultados de tratamiento. palabras-clave: ■ efecto coanda ■ perforaciones ■ pozo ■ formación Introduction This paper reviews efforts to simulate the behavior of fluid using a transient numerical computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulation software, FLUENT, and examines the study and application of transient characteristics of fluid phenomena for downhole PDs. Design parameters were selected and fined-tuned based on simulation results to achieve the desired frequency, mass flow rate (bbl/min), pressure drop, and outlet vector plot, etc. Virtual CFD simulation provided the discussed knowledge in advance. The fine-tuned design was prototyped and lab-tested for a wide range of inlet data. The testing results show consistent correlation with transient CFD simulation outcomes. The newly developed device has improved performance in all respects. The methodology adopted is in close agreement with the CFD numerical tool and was immensely beneficial to the development of this technology. Principle of Coanda effect Operation of this device is based on the Coanda effect. The Coanda or "wall attachment" effect was discovered by Romanian aerodynamicist Henri-Marie Coanda in 1930. He observed that a stream of fluid emerging from a nozzle tends to follow a nearby curved or angled surface if the curvature of the surface or angle is not too sharp. Problem definition During the life cycle of oil or gas wells, over a period of time, a loss of production or injectivity can occur, caused by NWB conductivity problems.Typical examples of those types of formation damage are: ■ Scales; ■ Paraffin; ■ Migrating fines; ■ Asphaltene deposits; ■ Lost or dehydrated drilling mud. Pulsating device and basic layout Figure4 shows a cross section of a device used to describe the concept. A narrow inlet throat is used to create a jet, which exits into the interior of the tool. The formed jet sticks to one of the angled interior surfaces by virtue of the Coanda effect described earlier. After the jet attaches to a surface, the fluid that forms the jet travels along the surface until it hits the entrance to the feedback loop. A larger portion of the fluid enters the feedback loop and exits the outlet port attached to the feedback loop. Some of the fluid travels past the outlet port and continues through the feedback loop, where it disrupts the attached jet and deflects it towards the other angled surface. The jet then attaches to the opposite surface, and the process continuously repeats itself, creating a steady oscillation of flow between the outlet ports, as shown in figure 4. Process methodology This paper addresses the study of fluid-flow characteristics and optimizing the design of a device for a desired oscillation frequency by selecting design parameters and including conceptual shapes. CFD analysis software ANSYS - FLUENT is extensively used to study fluid behavior with respect to time. Devices of several different sizes and configurations were simulated over a wide range of flow rates. Figure5 shows the overall process methodology adopted in this work (Roger and Chan, 2003). This analysis allowed for suitable changes to the geometry of the device, which improved performance and helped ensure reliable operation over the range of flow rates. ANSYS - FLUENT CFD setup Figure 6 illustrates a typical computational domain considered for a replica model of a PD. Transient solution is preferred to capture the inherent transient fluid-flow oscillation phenomenon described. The boundary conditions for the model consist of constant pressure applied at the inlet to the PD and zero pressure applied to the outlets. The properties of the working fluid used in the modeling were those of water. Pressures ranging from 500 to 2,000psi were used, resulting in flow rates between a few gallons per minute to some bbl/ min, depending on theouter diameter (OD) size of the device. Figure 7 shows the CFD software specific settings that were used. For quick results, atwo-dimensional (2-D) profile of a fluid-flow path was simulated, and, later, the detailed analysis was carried out with the help of a three-dimensional (3-D) simulation in FLUENT. Time discretization errors were avoided by reducing the time-step size. The time-step size used for this simulation was 1e-5 sec. The smaller the time-step size, the more the solution time; therefore, appropriate selection of time-step size is important for transient CFD simulations. As oscillation frequency is diminished, deeper energy penetration inside the formation is achieved which can yield greater hydrocarbon recovery, making the well more economical. Frequency of oscillation depends on parameters, such as the flow rate being pumped from the surface, annulus pressure, tool size (OD), and design of the oscillating chamber, etc. The efforts addressed here are specifically related to governing geometrical parameters (i.e., length of angled surfaces, angle of the oscillating chamber, length and width of feedback, etc.). The distance fluid flow travels between angled surfaces is defined by the included angle between the two surfaces. Within the considered tool size, the wider the angle is, the greater the separation between the walls. The selection of maximum angle depends on factors such as the wall attachment phenomenon observed in the Coanda effect. Under certain flow rates (velocity), the more separation between angled surfaces, the more time is required to switch the jet. It is known that oscillation frequency is inversely proportional to time; so, by controlling the angle, oscillation frequency can be controlled (fig. 8). Figure 8 - Parameter vs. Frequency. Another important feature is feedback loop design, where narrow openings will reduce the pressure differential between two feedback loops. The reduced pressure results in weak actuating pulses at the fluid switch, which causes further delay in switching. This delay in time further affects the oscillation frequency. Yet, another susceptible factor is the length of the angled wall. The oscillating frequency is related to the time it takes the fluid in the switched jet to travel along the angled surface to the inlet of the feedback loop. The transit time for the jet fluid is a function of the jet-fluid velocity and the length of the angled surface. The lower the jet-fluid velocity, the lower the oscillating frequency will be. Also, the longer the length of the angled surface, the lower the oscillation will be. Computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulation has been used extensively to investigate parameter performance. Manufacturability, cost, and product lifecycle were all factors considered during the design changes of the PD. Along with the goal of definite oscillation frequency, geometry was developed that allowed for a replaceable insert, metal-to-metal seals, and adaptability for use with other in-house device systems. During test setup, as depicted in figure 13, a specific fluid pump rate was established and held constant while the device was tested. A high-speed camera was used to capture the details of the fluid spray behavior. The video was captured at a rate of a few thousand frames per second, which was later used to calculate oscillation frequency. Conclusions The technique of using wellbore cleanout and NWB stimulation in conjunction with a PD has been known to the industry for many years. The effectiveness of the devicewas further enhanced by means of a CFD studyof the conventional devices, as shown in figure14. The various frequency ranges, configurations, sizes and patterns were made to suit the application. The proposed work involved CFD analysis, prototyping, and experimental correlation for the PD. A rigorous CFD analysis has been developed for the PD, which can be used for similar types of devices for development. It was observed that the new design is better in several aspects.
